title: Tardiba and Benji
address: Sandy Bay Road & St Georges Terrace, Battery Point
description: Two portraits featuring a Tasmanian Devil and Thylacine. Both representing Tasmanian icons.

title: Bonorong
description: Sunset silhouettes highlighting the need to slow down at dawn and dusk to save local wildlife and who to call if injured animals are found.

title: beAware of microplastics
description: The design of my box is inspired by art nouveau wallpaper, in particular the fish shape is based on the work of Koloman Moser. I have taken his gorgeous continuous pattern and manipulated it to conceptually express the impact of microplastics on our ocean life.

title: Dance with the Devil on Argyle
address: Argyle Street & Burnett Street, North Hobart
description: Incorporating a Tasmanian icon with the Scottish heritage that reflects Argyle & Burnett Streets.

title: Close Knit
address: Regent Street & Princess Street, Sandy Bay
description: This pop up forest joins the parade of trees along Regent, and other Sandy Bay streets, providing a thread of connection to the Eucalypt forest within which the nearby University campus dwells.  These decorated and yarn bombed versions, are designed to cause a little intrigue for commuters, and perhaps some reflection on nature in the urban environment.

title: Pack Mentality
address: Argyle Street, Pedestrian Crossing Near George Street, North Hobart
description: A herd of masks. Softened wool and sharpened teeth. The wolf amongst the sheep.

title: Secrets of Sandy Bay
address: Sandy Bay Road & King Street, Sandy Bay
description:
The Tale
Governor King hinted at the closure of Norfolk Island, softening to requesting volunteers to settle VDL, but only 5 family's did so, King responded, sending 500 people between 1807-1808.
Virgin soil, low stores, and poor tools awaited them, their descendants would be the beneficiaries of their toil. The settlers legacy can be traced by the seeds they brought with them, notably the Hawthorne Hedges and towering Norfolk Island Pines.

The Sentiment
"We have grown weary of the Governor, shoving us about the South Pacific, forcing our lot upon us, tearing us from the home we forged. Now, with aging bodies, meagre strength and diminished enthusiasm, we now work unfavourable ground. We suffered financial loss,and demand compensation. O must we start over again.

title: Untitled
address: Sandy Bay Road & Russell Crescent, Sandy Bay
description: A visual abstraction of the topographical road map of the Sandy Bay area located directly around the traffic control box.

title: The Seasons of Van Diemen's
description: Hobart's weather is very changeable. Tourists get a real sense of this when they walk out of the Travel Centre and into the headwind of a southerly icy gale. This is a lighthearted look at the seasons, with a high likelihood of experiencing all in one day.

title: Even This Shall Pass
description: The human form and the native Tasmanian species of fagus exploring changes and seasons through colour.

title: A Walk of Nature
description: Our fascinating bushwalking and wildlife spotting experience in Tasmania makes it natural to visualise our impression towards this beautiful state, where people, domesticated animal and wildlife can live together in harmony.

title: Safe With Us Now
description: Features 10 Murray St, a building earmarked for demolition - a fantasy where the building is rescued by Tasmanian Tigers and relocated.

title: Aspired
description: The artwork is a subconscious reflection on the mingling of natural and man-made environments.  Lines and colour create spontaneous harmonies.

title: From darkness we all can find the light
description:
This design portrays a young person feeling alone, scared and wrought with feelings of self harm and abandonment.  As a result of loving and supportive carers, the young person is able to move towards a brighter, happier future.
“Our artwork is trying to show how you can get from the dark side of life to the other by simply taking a chance. If you take that chance and step out of the darkness you'll find your life is more beautiful!”  Bek, 22 years old.

title: Such is Life
description: Designs from workshops conducted at Headway. An organisation involving people with brain injuries. They decided that they wanted their injuries to be the subject of the art work. These images were designed by headway participants.

title: At What Cost?
description: The Risdon Prison Project emphasised the beauty and value of Nature. In keeping with this environmental theme the design hilights iconic Tassie features such as Cradle Mountain and Wineglass Bay. The illusive Tasmanian Tiger is glimpsed and tracks are found growing in vines. The curves in this design mirror the architecture in the public space across the road and the design maintains a sense of fun and vibrancy.

title: Holiday Time
description: Oakdale Services clients Joy, Gary, Mary, Peter, Janine, Julie and Sandra had fun imagining where they would go or what they might do on vacation.

title: Tascare Society for Children
description: There is a community for everyone.

title: MADE
description: Ornate wallpaper

title: Island & Ocean
address: Elizabeth Street & Pedestrian Crossing, North Hobart
description: This is a depiction of our island culture and the intertwining of the ocean's resources as used by the Tasmanian Aboriginal community.  It also includes traditional symbols of importance to our community.

title: Totem Sun-Whale Eye
address: Elizabeth Street & Federal Street, North Hobart
description: It refers to Hobart’s history as a whaling port.

title: Community Friends
description: A collaboration between international university students and primary school children and their interpretation of community.

title: Summer Fun in Hobart
description: The students that designed this box wanted to show Tassie as 'the end of the rainbow', a treasure box full of surprises. They wanted to show all the great things that the Waterfront is known for (eg) yummy food, great times, the Sydney Hobart Yacht Race (they even researched the winner of the very first race). Of course they wanted to show the never ending struggle between seagulls and their love of hot chippies. They also wanted to acknowledge that the Signal Box is at the beginning of Elizabeth Street - and also to showcase the ever beautiful River Derwent.

title: No Trees No City
description: If there are no trees we have nothing.

title: The Many Layers of Bathurst Street
description: My Children wanted to show all the great things you could see from the Signal Box...there are shops, a library, a post office, a theatre, yummy food shops and lots of smiles from the locals, never forgetting the ever present traffic lights, sending us in lots of interesting and great directions...we love our city and we loved designing and showcasing the many layers of Bathurst Street.

title: Forever Young
address: Argyle Street, Near Royal Hobart Hospital, Hobart
description: Silhouttes of children from Hobart, all of whom have had some involvement with the hospital opposite.Now forever young, with symbols of Hobart painted within their frames; of river, mountain, earth and sun.

title: Our School in our Community
description: The Campbell Street logo with circles, hold continents of the world which represent our multicultural school.

title: Flicks
description: Students arrived at design because of proximity to major cinema complex.

title: Hands On Tasmania
artist: Tasmanian Polytechnic, Migrant Education Hands On English classes
description: New responses to Tasmania.

title: Sense of Place
description: Each face of the box corresponds with the mapped land beyond it. In other words, facing south down Harrington Street, the facet shows the map of the land beyond the box. At the top of each facet, the urban mapped landscape gives way to the land underneath, the land of the traditional custodians, the Mouheneenner People.

title: Live
description: The design represents health services which have been provided on this site 90 Davey St., historically and currently. The Community Rehabilitation Unit provides a physical rehabilitation service for outpatients. The blues in our design reflect health/hospital settings. Parts of human body represented indicate a focus on specific areas of the body in relation to the rehabilitation needs of individuals requiring skilled health workers in many disciplines to guide the rehabilitation process.

title: Catching Your Eye
description: This design is made up of the eye catching things that surround our block. It connects  key symbols of the school to the symbols of the urban environment in a bright and colourful way.

title: Scotch Thistle Tavern 1828
description: The site of the original Scotch Thistle tavern is on the opposite street corner. (Grey Building, on the other side of image with front of tavern showing).

title: The Brisbane Stack
description: The box located on the corner of Brisbane and Campbell streets, right outside a popular live music venue in Hobart so I made the box into an iconic stack of amps. The TSB celebrates live and local music in Hobart.

title: The Pigeons of Hobart
description: A tribute to our feathery friends.

title: Out of the Shadows
description:
A core group from Epilepsy Tasmania, Hobart worked together to produce artwork which represents the following: Epilepsy being unmasked in the community to reduce stigma and promote acceptance. The image incorporates participants' experience of the actual process of physical tests for example E.E.G, Neuro conductor studies and synapses monitoring.
 
It depicts emotions that tell of living with conditions such as isolation, loneliness, misunderstanding and the daily impact of epilepsy such as triggers including heat, flashing lights, tiredness and stress.

Participants have found various responses to epilepsy in the community both negative and positive- this is represented by the  movement throughout the design.

title: Seasons
description: Seasons of Hobart.

title: Crazy Flower Pattern
description: Hand-drawn flower pattern designed by young people that access the Youth Arts & Recreation Centre

title: Forests of the Sea
description: Giant Kelp forests create habitat of ecological and economic significance for iconic species such as the Southern Rock Lobster - important for Tasmanian fisheries. An overall decline of ~90% in this kelp has occurred over the past 50 years as warm, nutrient poor waters of the East Australian Current move further south, bringing sea urchin larvae which, when grown, go on to denude the abundant kelp forests; changing natural habitat and challenging the ecological balance for lobster and octopus populations.

title: Stump
description: A tree stump, made up of fine pattern.

title: Mandala
description: This artwork takes its inspiration from the colours of the local environment, ethnographic art and fractal geometry. The Mandala is a symbol of unity and the vines and design represent unity, peace, harmony and community. The design was initially inspired by the music video 'Proboscis' by Paradox Explorer.

title: Untitled
description: An exploration of the connections that exist throughout society.  I am particularly interested in social links and interconnections created by our experiences, relationships and thought.

title: Peace
description:
As The Friends' School is a quaker school we have decided to base our artwork and thinking for the signal box in Burnett St  around one of the quaker values, PEACE. We invited the
Kindergarten children to think what peace means to them. These are their comments:

There are lots of people around the world and they are are all being friends (Hannah).
The boats are drifting and bobbing in the sea (Raban).
The trees and snow are peaceful (Lochie).
The trees and flowers are friends (Andrew).
Ducks are swimming in the water peacefully (Harry).
The sun is friends with the trees (Haruka).
River, grass, and trees look peaceful (Sam).
Birds are peaceful (Jonas).

title: The Creature
description: A strange fishlike rainbow-serpent-inspired creature bursting out from the asphalt, containing the creative essence of Hobart.

title: Courage
description: This artwork is an imitation of various shaped, oxidized metal sheets, riveted together, with foliage growing from the joins, obscuring sections of the rusty background. Heavily textured sandstone also features.

title: Spotted Hand Fish and City of Gonad Jelly Fish
description: Detailed and bright illustrations of the Spotted Hand Fish and patterned images of the City of Gonad Jelly Fish.

title: The Angels' Share
address: Antill Street & Davey Street, South Hobart
description:
A celebration of the Tasmanian whisky industry, featuring imagery from the distillation process.  This design has been inspired by a variety of Tasmanian distilleries and depicts stills specific to Tasmanian whisky distilleries.
The box is located on one of Hobart

title: All Together
address: Main Road & Tower Road, New Town
description: We are a group of students studying in Hobart, Tasmania but we all come from many countries including Ethiopia, Thailand, Burma, Afghanistan, Iran and Pakistan.  We carry our cultures with us especially our languages.  We also carry hope that we can all live together safely in our new home and community with love, justice and friendship.

title: Sustainability Matters
address: Augusta Road & Pottery Road, Lenah Valley
description: A collaboration of Year 6 students from Lenah Valley Primary School highlighting the importance of acting sustainably and caring for our local and world environment.

title: Native Fauna - Lenah Valley
address: Augusta Road & Giblin Street, Lenah Valley
description: A tessellation of squares and rectangles in green shades forms the background. Silhouettes of native fauna serves as the foreground.

title: Fish Tank
address: Sandy Bay Road, Near Beach Road, Sandy Bay
description: Rather than treat the box as four flat surfaces to paint on, the students tried to incorporate the shape of the box into the artwork itself.  Firstly we thought of turning the box into a shop, and then a robot, but the idea we finally chose was a fish-tank.  In order for this to 'work' we needed to paint in a realistic style. The three grade six students who painted the box, researched tropical fish, and each chose a fish to reproduce on the electrical box. To ensure each individual fish was the same, the students made templates from recycled x-rays to help them. The seaweed, rocks etc. were added later.

title: Tasmanian Animals
address: Sandy Bay Road & Byron Street, Sandy Bay
description: Tasmanian animals by Albuera street Primary students.

title: Lions' Pride
address: Sandy Bay Road & Nelson Roads, Sandy Bay
description: As the box is located near our school we decided to show our pride in our school with a collection of lion paintings by our Pre-Kindergarten and Kindergarten boys.  The background will be Magenta which is also one of our school colours.

title: Forest Floor and Canopy
address: Macquarie Street & Antill Street, South Hobart
description: Orchid, fungi, leaf and fern. Some shapes and textures of natural forms found in Tasmania

title: Seagulls
address: Sandy Bay Road & Near Canice Avenue, Lower Sandy Bay
description: Seagulls at the beach

title: Locals...
address: Brooker Avenue & Burnett Street, North Hobart
description: Eastern Rosellas and Blue Gums are native to Tasmania - a common sight on the Domain across the freeway and in nearby parks. They bring a splash of colour to a busy industrial area.

title: Cloud Temple
description: Landscape/urbanscape referencing the Classical architecture, the iconic park and fountain in the near vicinity.

title: Parks, Stop and Enjoy
address: New Town Road & Argyle Street, New Town
description: Parks are a place to stop, enjoy and relax in. We looked at the surroundings, colours and things we enjoyed about the area. Birds are an important part of parks so we looked at the types of birds in the area. The images represent things in the  area and the colours of the seasons.

title: Community Radio Hobart
description: This artwork is based around an outer space design with musical notes zooming around like shooting stars.  The artwork is based upon the idea of radio waves and their invisible presence within our atmosphere.

title: Squares and Rectangles. But mostly Rectangles
address: New Town Road & Forster Street, New Town
description: Using vibrant colours, throwing in metallic, about the urban life and all the repetitive shapes and geometric lines, but giving it vibrancy and making it fun.

title: Highway colour
description: Traffic lights, headlights, tail-lights, complimented by houses, trees and flowers in the gardens and median strips.

title: Space Anime
description: various anime images are suspended in scenes from the universe.

title: Rap Around
description: A multi-coloured design hinting at an abstracted Hobart landscape that wraps around the box along with a spiralling text message where the tail end of one word forms the beginning of the next to provide verbal cues that shift depending on where your focus falls.

title: Wycinanki Waratah
address: Elizabeth Street, New Town Road, New Town
description: Design is inspired by Polish embroidery and Tasmanian Flora and Fauna in response to the location of the signal box outside the Polish Club in New Town (Hobart) Tasmania.

title: Our River Derwent
address: Sandy Bay Road & Gladstone Street, Battery Point
description: This design depicts the Derwent River on which Hobart, Tasmania's capital city is situated. It features replica Brig the "Lady Nelson" along with some marine life that visit our beautiful waters.

title: Urban Footprint
description: Slick design,cool colours and smart detailed brush work act as a bold reminder to the presence of our 4 legged friends and the balance society must obtain between our natural and urban environment.

title: Peace and Freedom
description: Abstract flowing rainbow design featuring a dove and a Tasmanian wedge-tailed eagle soaring amidst the colours.

title: Love, Joy & Peace in Hobart
description: We love Hobart. This design represents Hobart with the fish representing people from different nationalities coming here. The dove represents peace, the hearts represent love and the music notes - joy.

title: Berry Hungry
description: Silver gulls squabble over a cherry. This piece references the nearby IXL Jam Factory, and the proliferation of gulls along Hobart's waterfront.

title: We are Learners
description: An exploration of colour (Primary & Secondary Colours via Rainbow Flowers) with the Lansdowne Crescent Primary School Kinders 2017

title: Pitt Farm
address: Main Road & Creek Rroad, New Town
description: Picture and information on Pitt Farm which has historical value, not only to Newtown, Tasmania, but also to Australian heritage as its is the second farmhouse that was built in our free settlement origins.

title: Box 9196
description:
The design of the box takes its inspiration from the names of the intersecting streets:
The tartan pattern is the tartan of the Campbells of Argyll in Scotland after whom the street was supposedly named by Lachlan Macquarie. 
The bear and billet elements come from the county coat of arms of Warwickshire, UK -  Warwick St was so named because it was the home town of Surveyor-General of Tasmania, George William Evans. However the bear and billet symbol has never struck me as very nice, so in this design the bear is free of its chain. This also reflects Hobart

title: Mountains of Time
description: A colourful depiction of Southern Tasmanian landscape. Featuring Mount Wellington, Hartz Peak and the Tasman Bridge.

title: Antarctic
description: The artwork represents Hobart connection with the Antarctic as well as its location as a base. Hobart icons are people and the bridge which are associated with the Antarctic represented by the animals. The distance travelled and the link as a base are represented by the wandering albatroses and the red hulled ship (Aurora Australis)

title: Tasmanian Red Handfish
description: Endemic to Tasmania, the red handfish uses its fins to 'walk' across the seafloor. With less than 1000 remaining in the wild, this artwork seeks to raise awareness and encourage protection of this unique fish.

title: Chairs
description: A nod to Mr Arthur Prudy, Chairs speaks of local history, referencing his second hand furniture business, which ran in the lane for 27 years. These quirky characters sit on antique chairs, carefully keeping watch on Purdys Mart.

title: MOBIUS STRIP
artist: Chooka, Aedan Howlett, Seven, Odi, Lukan Smith
description: MOBIUS STRIP is a 5-minded reflection on the ocean, Styles, colours and ideas clashing like waves-creating an aquatic harmony. With many individual stories told, the story for the viewer is let to their own imagination.

title: Sprout
description: Sprout is a discussion about consumerism and in particular, everyday recyclable material. I've done this by attracting city goers using vibrant colours against an almost harsh white wall, allowing them to reflect upon its deeper meaning and what they can take from it.

title: Lost giant
description: Lost Giant is a character in a global story. With his smartphone's GPS in hand, he sets out on a journey to discover the city himself. Share the journey as he navigates the streets of Hobart.

title: Teraform
description: Teraform is a weed pushing through a crack. It's some far off jungle. Your mildly disturbed neighbour's overgrown yard. A rouge bacteria clinging to a probe on Mars. R maybe just the kind of place where car wrecks go to be swallowed.

title: Trapdoor
description: Trapdoor takes passers-by on a tourney through a dark dungeon cave filled with treasure and crystals. Influenced by various cartoons, including a 1990's tv show of the same name, Trapdoor is a nostalgic connection to a 1990s childhood.

title: Rodent Six
description: Re-imaging object and artefacts from the pop culture that surrounded children growing up in the 1990s. Virtual pets and portable game console inhabit vivid memories of tender moments, looming over us forever with dreaming eyes and rose coloured cheeks.

title: Everyone Needs a Hand Sometimes
description: As these characters push and swing, we see the idea of giving and taking and working together to create the equilibrium required to maintain the balance of everyday life, set against the backdrop of Hobart's hanging urban landscape.

title: Birds of a Feather
description: I've been inspired by the cheeky and playful character of birds for this work. My aim is to create and engaging mural using pattern and repetition to give a sense of movement and draw people in to use their imaginations.

title: YOU'RE HERE
description: YOU'RE HERE calls on viewers to pause as they enter the underpass and reflect on their physical, mental or emotional 'here'. This open ended phrase can be read in literal or complex ways, dependent upon personal experience.
